Array

An Array is an object used by JavaScript to make lists. These lists can store different data types in an ordered way meaning the position of each list item is numbered/indexed by JavaScript to make them easy to find. They are constructed of square brackets, which contain a list of items separated by commas.

Create an Array

Here we can create an empty array:

                        

var array = [];

If we use the typeof() function on the array it will return 'object' as it's data type, not array.

                        

var array = [];
typeof(array);    // returns: 'object'

In this example, each item in the shoppingList array is a string, but you can store any type of item in an array: string, number, object, variable, even another array.

                        

var shoppingList = [ 'bread', 'milk', 'cheese', 'fruit', 'noodles' ];
shoppingList;   // Output the array

Access an Array item

Each item in the array has a numbered position. This is it's index. We can access a specific item using it's index. JavaScript counts from 0 and not 1, so the first item in the array will always have the index of 0. This is because JavaScript is zero-indexed.

We want to get milk from our shoppingList array. This item has the index of 1. You can access the individual items in the array using bracket notation.

                        

shoppingList[1];  // returns: 'milk'

You can also modify an item in an array by simply giving the item a new value. Let's remove 'milk' from our shoppingList and replace it with 'hot chocolate'.

The shoppingList array will now return:

Length property

You can find out the number of items an array contains - the length of the array - using the length property.

                        

shoppingList.length;   // returns: 5
